Our waiter ( I forgot his name) went out of his way to make the experience top notch...which it was. They had limo's pick us up and take us to the show and the show itself was side splitting! If you are looking for a great weekend get away this is it! Everyone had a GREAT time!!

Reviews.Title: “New property, convenient location, business-oriented but can get overpriced”
Reviews.Author: 1North
Reviews.Content: Stayed there twice for a total of 6 nights in April. Both stays booked directly through hotel website. For the first stay there were excellent deals on offer starting at $105. However for the second (shorter) stay, booked at short notice the rates were over double that, due probably to the high occupancy level the hotel was enjoying as a result of a large convention it was hosting at the time. This is a new property and two blocks from Market Street, easy self-parking behind the hotel ($40 per day) and less than a 5 minute walk to SF Shopping Centre (Bloomingdales) and not a lot further to Macys and Union Square. The Powell Street tram stop is also close too. The rooms were comfortably furnished (minimalistic/modern) and of acceptable size. On our first visit the bathrooms had tubs but no walk-in shower cubicle but on our second visit we had no tubs but a walk-in shower. On neither occasion did the hotel manage to allocate us interconnecting rooms despite a request made at the time of booking. Internet connection of $20 per day was steep. We did not dare touch the minibar fridge lest the sensors ring up a charge. The in-room safe was small - just big enough for a regular laptop plus some documents and valuables. Room insulation noise-wise was not great - slamming doors along the corridor reverberated along the walls, and conversations from the rooms next door and from out in the corridor could be detected without difficulty. We did not take any meals at the hotel so cannot comment, but the bar area was well-patronised. There was a long queue for checking out but this can be by-passed by calling the operator and checking out over the phone. In the overall scheme of things this is just another one of those hotels which does everything well enough but nothing in particular stands out to really differentiate it from others of its like. Would I stay there again? Yes but only if I could find a discounted rate as I don't believe their regular rates justify the product.

Reviews.Title: “Great Value! Modern, comfortable, excellent location!”
Reviews.Author: charlie15
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Intercontinental over the Easter week end. I was really pleased with the hotel. It is a very modern building, well located 2 blocks away of the Powell station and the Cable Car and Market Street and 5 blocks from Union Square. The Check in was breezy and the front desk guy was really courteous. The room on the 25 floor was really nice with great view of the city. The room was big, clean, quiet, up-to-date and the bed and pillows super comfortable. The bathroom was roomy and clean as well. I had a free wireless connection as part of my deal. (Excellent signal), The concierge service is top notch. They are very friendly and helpful with directions and information and bend over backwards to help. I didnâ€™t have Breakfast at the hotel. (@ $ 20 a day too expensive for my taste). It was the right choice since a block or two away, I found a couple of nice restaurants offering solid Bfasts for less than $ 10. Overall, excellent and quality place to stay in SFO. I will not mind staying there again!

Reviews.Title: “LOVE THIS HOTEL”
Reviews.Author: lizsp33
Reviews.Content: I stayed here recently for business and I loved this hotel. The rate was just under $200 a night, which seems like a steal considering how luxurious this place is. My only complaint is that the parking is expensive at $50 or so per day, but since I'm not familiar with the area I didn't know of any other alternatives. Also, I would call ahead for my car, but they never had my car ready. I started to think calling ahead was useless, and that they don't actually get your car for you until you go downstairs and request it. The rooms were amazing. I had a corner room and the exterior walls were all windows. The furniture and carpets are new and the beds are comfy. Not only do the rooms have flat screen TVs, but they have HD programming! I was so excited about this. Many hotels nowadays have the flat screen TVs, but IMO that is useless unless you actually provide the HD channels to go with it. The TVs were also a good size, my guess is 46". I ordered room service a few times. It was a little pricey, but I thought the food was pretty good. Definitely better than most hotels. And the prices were probably in line with the city. I also used the gym which was really nice - lots of equipment and they provided headphones for the TVs. I would definitely stay at this hotel again, and I would definitely consider staying at Intercontinental hotels in other locations because of the great experience I had in San Francisco.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel! Couldn't be happier”
Reviews.Author: MarieTess
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I stayed here for a fun-filled weekend in SF and Napa, and we really couldn't be happier with our decision. Generally this hotel may be on the pricier side (but worth every penny), but I found an amazing deal on Travelzoo and got the room for a great price. We stayed at the Intercontinental for 3 nights which allowed us to properly feel out their amenities and services ... friendly and informative staff (see Durian for all the great SF hot spots and hidden gems), excellent fitness room, immaculate rooms and common areas, and great food! Parking at the hotel tends to be pretty expensive ($50+ for overnight parking with in/out privileges). There is a parking lot a block away if you are looking to save a couple dollars ... it isn't the cheapest parking lot, but you do save a few bucks if you don't plan parking your car there for a lengthy amount of time ($3 for the 1st hour .... ~$30 for 12 hours or more). Parking in SF does not come cheap, so these rates can be expected in the area. Lastly, the location is great .. especially for shopping. We didn't shop much .. more of a sight seeing and wine country visit. This hotel would be convenient for someone who plans to help boost the economy and do some damage in the shops!

Reviews.Title: “More focus on yuppie amenities than practical needs”
Reviews.Author: SciTravel
Reviews.Content: The hotel provided copies of Esquire magazine and an iPod alarm clock, but was going to charge nearly $20 a day for internet service. Also, a coffee brewer with "complimentary" coffe pods was tucked into the mini bar. However, at check-in I was told that the mini bar was equipped with a motion detector and I would be charged for anything that was moved-I didn't even want to try to get the coffee maker out. Overall, practical considerations just didn't seem to be there, such as being able to use free internet or turn the shower on without getting doused in cold water. I guess it just depends what you are looking for in a hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Great place to stay”
Reviews.Author: aalguire
Reviews.Content: - built in 2008 - near downtown SF - Great buffet breakfast but include this option when you book the hotel or it's quite expensive - great beds and pillows - showers are large and excellent - fitness center is the best. They even provide free snacks - very friendly people - internet access is not free - lots of very fast elevators - in room Timothy coffee

Reviews.Title: “Wow!”
Reviews.Author: moviegirl51
Reviews.Content: My husband and I along with our dog took a "California Staycation" at the Intercontinental and had a great time. I am extremely picky and I could not find anything wrong with this place. The room was spotless (no dust anywhere), the bed was dreamy (fluffy pillows, down comforter) and the bathroom was large with a marble sink. In our package we received free valet parking ($50 value), free buffet breakfast ($60 value) and $10 gas card for about $160 a night (with taxes and all the fees). The staff was wonderful and we had a great time. We will definitely stay at another Intercontinental hotel in the future.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel but would not rush back”
Reviews.Author: brightonrockboys
Reviews.Content: Stayed in this hotel for 3 nights on our first visit to sf. We were initially allocated a room on the 15th floor but the view was nothing great so decided to pay $100 pn for an upgrade to a better room. The actual room we upgraded to had a much better view (32nd floor!) although ironically the room was smaller!!!! The upgrade also allowed us to use the 'executive' facilities on the lower 6th floor - continental breakfast which was really good and evening drinks/canapes. Unfortunately the 3rd morning it felt more like a kids club rather than an executive club and has very limited capacity. The staff at this hotel were all very friendly and the rooms pretty comfortable.

Reviews.Title: “Nice bed and great view - average service and no atmosphere”
Reviews.Author: TravellingViking1977
Reviews.Content: Stayed in the Intercontinental San Francisco Fri 17th to Sun 19th. Have booked entire stay in California with the IHG group using my company corporate rate. Not cheap by any means - but based on dates and availablity of other hotels not too bad either. Handy location only a couple of minutes walk from Powell St BART station. First impression of the hotel - nice and clean but no atmosphere whatsoever. Like checking into a clinic. Check-in and subsequent trip down to reception to revalidate the keys were less than encouraging - like talking to robots trained by US immigration staff. All I wanted was to get my room key working - not get a 35 point listing of the hotel rules for key re-validation. On the positive side - got room on the 27th floor with amazing view through floor to ceiling windows. Room was nice and clean with VERY comfy bed. Large flatscreen, desk, armchair - bathroom bigger than average with walk in shower. Ordered room service Saturday night - very nice food, great presentation and decent portions. Free newspaper delivered daily. Toiletries and coffee/tea were not restocked. All in all a decent place to stay. For business probably one of the best in town - for leisure it just didn't do it for me.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful”
Reviews.Author: MeetingProDC
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for 2 nights and was very happy with everything. I had a corner room so all my walls were floor to ceiling windows. I had beautiful views of the city. There was always staff in the lobby willing to be of assistance. I would stay here again. no complaints!

Reviews.Title: “Recommended â€“ at a price”
Reviews.Author: NikNak586
Reviews.Content: We arrived at the hotel and despite requesting over two months ago in writing (and paying for) a suite on a high floor, plus calling to confirm the day before, we were offered a room down on the 8th floor (as nothing else was apparently available). After having made our displeasure very clear with receptionist and being sent to a tiny alternate room on a higher floor, we were eventually given exactly the type of room weâ€™d booked, a suite on the 22nd floor. Why this couldnâ€™t have happened at the beginning I donâ€™t know â€“ not the best greeting by the hotel (especially after a long flight)! That said, the rest of our one week stay was excellent. The concierge (Bill) couldnâ€™t have been more helpful, the doormen were always smiling and facilities like the pool, gym, room service were as good as youâ€™d expect. If I had any other criticism it would be the secondary costs. The price of their breakfast is simply not worth considering, especially when just 5 mins walk away there is the excellent Melâ€™s Diner, offering a substantial meal for less than half the price. If you want really top class food while youâ€™re in San Francisco I canâ€™t recommend highly enough either Scomas Seafood (Pier 47, Fishermanâ€™s Wharf) or the classic Tadich Grill (240 California St.).

Reviews.Title: “Nice new hotel - not the best location though”
Reviews.Author: melachocolat
Reviews.Content: The hotel is brand new and the rooms have been done very nicely. I stayed in a junior suite and what I loved most about it was that it was located at a corner of the building and two of the room walls were completely turned into window fronts which gives faboulous day light and even better views over the town. The same was done with the bathroom. You could soak in your bath and look out on San Fran. This simply cannot be topped. Staff were all very smiley and helpful and some even remembered my name - which I feel is always a bonus. The only thing was that my "please do not disturb" sign was overlooked twice. Food: the chef has been awarded best new comer. I met her and she is lovely and down to earth. When it comes to the cuisine it is a somehow undefinable fusion of European, Middle Eastern and Asian. It was good but for my taste there was too much going on. However it was certainly adventurous - eg the rye ice cream. The quality of breakfast however was dissappointing. Location wise Market and Union Square are only a five minute walk away. Everything else would need to be done by cab. The area itself looks rough and I would not walk around at night which is a shame. The hotel has a spa, a gym and a pool. Don't expect to be wowed away though. I have not tried the spa, but the gym and pool are - as to be expected from an Interconti - very corporate. The pool looked even not very well maintained.

Reviews.Title: “New hotel in upcoming neighborhood”
Reviews.Author: Butcher.T
Reviews.Content: We have stayed at the Intercontinental before. The room we had this time was a king bed standard room. The hotel offers all the amenities that most large chain hotels offer. Printing of boarding passes is free. Parking at the hotel is high at $56/night with in and out privileges. Blue Bottle Coffee is just down from the hotel on Mint Street off 5th Street. They offer a limited breakfast and good coffee. The hotel is close to MOMA, the Moscone Center, the new Jewish Museum and Yerba Buena Park where you can find some nice spots for lunch. The hotel often offers deals through Travelzoo, Orbitz, Expedia and other online sites as well as it's own website.

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous stay at the Intercontinental San Francisco”
Reviews.Author: Desertbrat4now
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just returned from a great two night stay at the Intercontinental San Francisco. We are very hard to please, but I must say, our stay was way, way beyond expectation. The hotel was immaculate, the service five star...in fact, everything was five star. I loved the room, the view, the bed, the dining room and room service. The best part...it was quiet...it was away from the hustle of Union Square...all those sirens. We actually got good sleep....incredible. Thank you....a job well done.

Reviews.Title: “One of the best hotels I've ever stayed in!”
Reviews.Author: lucidlilies
Reviews.Content: I have stayed in many hotels for business so I have seen my share of good and bad hotels. However, nothing compares to my stay at the Intercontinental San Francisco! The bed is seriously the most comfortable, luxurious bed I've ever been in, hands down. They use a feather bed and a feather comforter which makes it very hard to get up in the mornings. Also, although I wasn't in the room much, the view from the room was spectacular (had a view of the bay). Try to get one of these rooms on the upper floors. The room itself is quite large and the bathroom is amazing. I do wish there was a bit more counterspace. The shower is enormous but wish there was a tub to sit in after a long day. If you are in town for business and want a nice place to stay in a central location (it's close to the Westfield, Moscone, FIDI) then stay at this hotel! I look forward to staying here again soon.

Reviews.Title: “Modern hotel close to Convention Center”
Reviews.Author: ijjy
Reviews.Content: Beautiful new hotel and modern rooms. Complimentary fruit platter and mineral water on check-in with Intercontinental Ambassador Card. Good location for Conference at Convention Center down the road. Short walk to shopping area downtown and to the cable car stop in town. Catch the cable car to Fisherman's Wharf. The 'San Franciscan' at Fisherman's Wharf has excellent crabs, and Boudin's (chains throughout San Francisco) is excellent for lunch rolls and the famous calm chowder bread bowls. Grocery store (within shopping complex) close to hotel - for snacks and water supplies. Visitor Information Center downtown were very helpful- be sure to see them and get a one-page flyer from them with all the top tourist spots in San Francisco (has all the bus numbers you need to get there). Can get a 3-day, 5-day or 7-day travel pass from the Visitor Center- allows unlimited trips on trains, buses, and cable car (much cheaper than paying $5 for cable car per trip). Book the Alcatraz tour early as often booked out in the high season. Breakfast at Intercontinental was expensive, and not much range. If you don't like the scrambled eggs, don't ask for poached eggs or omelette, as this is an additional charge ($19 on top of the $35-40 you pay for the full American breakfast). Chente is an excellent waiter with a good attitude. Make sure you check the charges carefully at check-out as there were additional incorrect gratuities added on to our breakfast bill, and other mistakes. Liked: Location; modern new rooms Disliked: Poor range at breakfast; many incorrect charges on bill

Reviews.Title: “Convenient location, good service, modern and clean”
Reviews.Author: HK_Amanda
Reviews.Content: My husband was in San Francisco for a conference and we stayed at the Inter-Continental SF for five nights. The hotel is modern, sleek and convenient located - right next to the Moscone Convention Centre, 2 blocks from the cable car terminal, 1 block from Bloomingdales and Nordstrom and a 10-minute walk from Union Square, where more shops await. The room was spacious, clean and modern, equipped with flat-screen TV and i-pod dock. The only complaint is that the shower was very weak - it was one of those fixed ones (as opposed to a hand-held one) and there was no temperature control, which was rather surprising for a new hotel. Our package came with breakfast included so we enjoyed their buffet breakfast every day. The selection was limited and remained exactly the same for our entire stay. Staff were helpful and attentive, especially the concierge who provided us with excellent tips and recommendation.

Reviews.Title: “Best hotel stay in a LONG time!!!”
Reviews.Author: Julie A
Reviews.Content: From the moment of arrival, every staff member acknowledged us and made us feel welcome. The hotel is very modern and in a great, convenient location. Check in was a breeze. We had a great view in a Queen bed room on the 27th floor. The room was on the small side, but as a couple, we didn't need any more space. There was a huge wall-mounted plasma tv, which was great for watching a movie at the end of the night. We were able to get an in-room movie that was a movie that is still in the theaters. It was great! The shower was really big and the bathroom was immaculate. The bedding was luxurious, and the "do not disturb" switch at the door was particularly convenient. Overall, this was one of the best hotel stays that I have had in a long time. The concierge was particularly helpful by providing us direction on where to eat near the hotel and providing packing tape and a marker for the box of wine we were taking home. I got a great deal on this room on H*otwire, but after staying here, I would be willing to pay the regular rate.

Reviews.Title: “Great for a weekend getaway”
Reviews.Author: gcjones
Reviews.Content: We stayed here one night as we were in town to hear the San Francisco Symphony. Interesting urban area with many restaurants, diners, etc close by. Short walk to BART and Union Square. Located in the SOMA, the neighborhood has its share of interesting inhabitants, but we never felt unsafe. Wonderful room on the 28th floor. There are other options in the neighborhood for breakfast, such as Mel's Diner on 4th & Mission. Or, indulge yourself with room service... Staff was attentive and helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Nice modern hotel”
Reviews.Author: VictoriaLA
Reviews.Content: We stayed in this hotel for one night. It's new, the rooms are nice, the view is OK. It's very modern style, so I would not call it cozy. Price is pretty high too. Nice business center. The reception area provides free iced tea. Parking is crazy expensive. Location is just great, nice area.

Reviews.Title: “Short Break Away”
Reviews.Author: visit11
Reviews.Content: Having read all the prior reviews i imagined this would be a hotel in the middle of the business district a long way from the sites of San Francisco, with limited appeal. Actually this is in a great location, 300 yards from the heart of the central shopping areas, 300 yards from the main tram line and a yet not noisey at night. Compared to the hotels down by the wharf (Blackpool on a Sunny Day) this is a great base to ensure you see the rest of the City. Although very expesive at the hotel bar ($20 for 2 drinks). I would recommend the saloon on Powell street just before Union square for $2.95 Margaritas, the cheapest bar in town and right in the middle of the restaurant areas. Lefty O'Doulls on Geary Street is also a great place for a cheap lunch with a nice pint. The concierge in the hotel are exceptionally knowledgable and helpful and we made ful use of them. The breakfast at $28 is unreasonable, but Little Joes restaurant 200 yards away on 5th street has all you can imagine for a third of the cost.

Reviews.Title: “Very Modern”
Reviews.Author: saturncmc
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Intercontinental in San Francisco for 2 nights on business. The hotel is about a year old and very modern. The room was large and the bed was comfortable. There was a huge flat screen TV which was great. With floor to ceiling windows, there's a nice view. The bathroom was big with a large glass enclosed shower with good water pressure (14th floor). There was a bathroom scale and this is the first time I have ever seen one in a hotel. The food in the hotel was ok but the breakfast buffet is very expensive, about $40. I took a cab to Fisherman's wharf for $12 and it was well worth the trip. There is lots to see and do. Great restaurants too. You can see Alcatraz from the dock and there is a ferry that takes you there for a tour. It costs $26 and is a great tour with audio headsets in every language. I wish the hotel was closer to the wharf, because with limited time, I couldn't see everything.

Reviews.Title: “Hold on to your wallet”
Reviews.Author: Ed-Bogus
Reviews.Content: Hold on to your pocketbook. While the rooms here are adequate and the views outstanding, I was shocked at the level of pilfering that starts when you walk in the door. $14.95 for an internet hookup in the room? It only starts there. When we went downstairs where my company had booked a meeting room....the price for internet access was $80 plus a fee to turn the service on. A polycom phone. More than $300! A projector? Let's just say it was cheaper for us to go buy our own. No kidding, that's what we did. Add the indifferent service and you've got a promise that my company will never do business here again.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent rooms, good view, a few minutes away from Union Square”
Reviews.Author: Cooki
Reviews.Content: We spent 6 days at the Intercontinental in San Francisco and the hotel consistently delivered on all counts. The hotel is fairly new, and this shows in the modern design and spacious rooms. Our room was on a high floor, and we had a good view across the city and further on to the bay. The bed was very comfortable, and the room also had a large 42" lcd. the bathroom has a large walk-in shower, but no bathtub. The whole length of one wall in the room is lined by windows, making the room very bright and airy. The service is excellent at all levels - efficient and quick valet parking, a knowledgeable and helpful concierge, friendly housekeeping. We ordered room service on a few occasions and felt that the food, although not stellar, was certainly at a very good level. The only slight negative was that the air conditioning didn't seem to work evenly in the room and bathroom, and the bathroom remained rather cold. I also would have liked better shower pressure - this wasn't bad, but it wasn't a proper power shower either. The hotel is well-located, right next to the Moscone convention center and only a couple of blocks away from Union Square. I enjoy walking, so the few minutes that it took to get to the more happening parts of town did not bother me. Finally, the hotel itself has an excellent restaurant, Luce, that is certainly worth trying. I would definitely recommend this hotel, both for business and leisure travelers - an excellent example of Intercontinental quality.

Reviews.Title: “wonderful views”
Reviews.Author: salaciouscrum
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Intercontinental for a weekend getaway. We had originally booked a standard king room, but decided to upgrade to the executive king room, for an extra $60 per night. I thought it was well worth it, since the view of downtown was amazing, especially at night. I never felt cramped in the room like I do at other hotels. Liked the little touches, such as the robes and sensor lighting when you entered the room. Only snafu was with the bill since we wanted to split it between cards. Upon checkout we noticed there was one card being charged. But we brought this to the clerk's attention and it was fixed. Didn't go to the bar or restaurant, but the gym and spa looked pretty nice. Don't understand why they charge for wifi. I guess the area can be a little seedy at night if you're not used to an urban setting; otherwise a fantastic stay

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel with "Modern Problems"”
Reviews.Author: JimmyMc
Reviews.Content: This Intercontinental is less than a year old, and is what you'd expect in a new, five-star hotel in a major city. It does have a range of "modern hotel problems", however. I was upgraded to a nice, high-floor corner room due to my Ambassador Club status. Hotel was pretty empty, despite a major convention at Moscone Center (a block away). Rooms are tastefully appointed, clean and comfortable. A/C system is particularly good, very quiet. However, when I first checked in, I was warned that a "maintenance issue" would require the hotel electricity to be turned off for an hour that afternoon. Fair enough. But during the late night hours, while I was working (phone and internet), the power again went out along with all communications - AND THE ELEVATORS. No warning at all. This pattern of electrical service continued for the next day as well. Apparently still-unresolved construction issues. The phones go down because of a too-small UPS system specified. My other "modern hotel" pet peeve is the showers. Part of luxury hotel life is a good, powerful hot shower. Instead this hotel has barely enough water pressure to get wet. If this is due to some kind of "green initiative", I object. If this is just due to bad water-saving shower heads, it should be fixed. Midline management was dismissive of the concerns I raised. I was able to finally raise the hotel manager with a call to IC head office about the electrical/communication issues. Management shouldn't be hiding from the customers. One other note for potential visitors - much of SFO including the area adjacent to this hotel has become extremely street unsafe, even during the daytime. Factor in cab fares if you're planning on doing sightseeing.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic Hotel. Will definitely return”
Reviews.Author: SR32
Reviews.Content: We had a fantastic 7 night stay at the Intercontinental San Francisco. The location is perfect being 2 blocks away from Market Street and Shopping etc. Staff courteous at all times and couldn't do enough really. The beds are fantastic (my one key requisite when booking a hotel room) and the linens are superb. Will definitely return on our next trip to San Francisco.

Reviews.Title: “Great place for our anniversary”
Reviews.Author: SFShush
Reviews.Content: I stayed here in early January as a staycation for my five year anniversary. My boyfriend and I booked it on hotwire for $140 including all taxes ($119 before taxes). It was listed as Union Square East, which is not really accurate since it's in SOMA, but it was still in an area that was nice enough. We live here so the homeless don't surprise us, but if you're coming from a non-urban area anywhere in SF is going to have that problem. If it had been located one block south or west it would not be in a good location, but it was right inside what we consider to be the border of the upscale area downtown. We got there early in the day and left our bags with the bellhop. I lost my ticket when we came back, but he was able to retrieve them with my driver's license, which was a relief. Everyone was so polite we were sort of taken aback. Check in took only a few minutes, and we explained why we were there when asked. We got booked into a queen size room on the 14th floor (1405 I belive). When we got to the room I was very disappointed with the size. It couldn't have fit a king size bed had someone put it in there. The bathroom was even more disappointing as it didn't have a bathtub and I really wanted to soak my feet after walking around all day. I went downstairs and asked if it would be possible to be moved to a room with a bathtub. His response was "It's your anniversary, of course you can!" which was a relief. We got moved to the 9th floor to a king size room. It was about twice the size and had a separate shower and bath. That changed it from a 2-3 star to a five star experience. We took advantage of the jacuzzi and swimming pool twice in less than 24 hours. Both were such great temperatures and the jacuzzi was big enough that even when an entire family came in there was plenty of room. The TV was huge and we almost rented a movie but decided against it. Most cost between 10-14 dollars, and include those that are in between theatre and DVD. Bed was a little soft for my taste, but my boyfriend loved it. The blankets were plush and wonderful. This was a perfect escape for one night, and if I could get this price again I would stay there in an instant.

Reviews.Title: “A flawless stay”
Reviews.Author: tympan
Reviews.Content: Just back from a great stay at the InterContinental in San Francisco, one of the best and most hassle-free hotel stays I've had in a long time. This brand-new hotel is convenient, comfortable, and peaceful, with big rooms and smooth, unobtrusive service. Everything just works really well here. Highly recommended. The hotel occupies a soaring blue-glass tower in the trendy South of Market (SOMA) neighborhood; it's two blocks south of Market Street, the main downtown thoroughfare, and maybe a 10-minute walk from Union Square. The decor is sleek and modern, but not too aggressively cool; the lobby is relatively low-key, with a bar and restaurant, giving the comfortable feel of a smaller hotel even though the hotel is quite large. My room, on the 17th floor, was impressively spacious, well-appointed, and tricked out with the latest gadgets, from the motion-sensor light in the entry to the huge high-def flat-screen TV. But unlike a lot of new hotels, the space had been designed very intelligently; the wall unit had ample room for desk space and a long counter, and a window seat and a long ledge in the bathroom gave the sense of additional space to spread out. The bed was very comfortable, with super-soft pillows. The bathroom was also big, with a glassed-in shower. I had decent views from the very big windows toward Union Square and the Civic Center. If you're sensitive to noise, you'll like this: the hotel is impressively quiet. Entering your room is like stepping into a cocoon of silence. There's almost no street noise. I was returning to my room one evening and could hear my neighbor talking very loudly on his phone through his door; but once I entered my room I couldn't hear a thing. Service was smooth and efficient but unobtrusive. There was always someone standing in the lobby to greet you. Wake-up calls were delivered on time, and room service arrived promptly. Housekeeping kept the room very clean. A bonus: the hotel's food is excellent. I didn't eat in the restaurant, Luce, but I had a fantastic Luce burger at the bar (San Francisco has some odd ideas about how to season french fries, but they were still good), and a delicious chicken and eggplant panini from room service. The only possible drawback to the hotel is the location; it's a little off the beaten path, and the block it's on is a little desolate. However, it is right next to the Moscone Center and just a block or two away from the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, Yerba Buena Gardens, and Metreon, and it's just two blocks south of the Powell Street BART/Muni station. (Hint: If you're coming here from SFO and traveling light, don't take a taxi, which will cost a fortune and take forever; BART will zip you straight from the airport to Powell Street in about 30 minutes for just over $5.) There's also a stiff charge ($15/day) for in-room Internet access, but that's true of almost all luxury hotels; at least the network was reasonably fast. Overall, this is a fantastic place to stay, especially for the business traveler or the seasoned tourist who wants to be a little bit away from the hustle and bustle.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the InterContinental”
Reviews.Author: cbcTraveler333
Reviews.Content: Husband and I enjoyed our stay at the InterContental. We live in the Bay Area and stayed one evening to enjoy the City during the holiday season. When we arrived, service was superb -- greeted warmly by the doorman, check in person, bartender and everyone else we came into contact with -- all very professional and welcoming. We requested a corner room at check-in which was great with floor to ceiling windows. The room was well appointed (reasonable size for city standards) and had a plasma TV. The feel of the hotel is modern and clean. We found a great price at $129 for the night and would return. Thanks to other posters, we knew the valet parking charge was considerable and took public transportation which worked out great in the City â€“ this is the way to go if you can. While we were there, we enjoyed dinner at Town Hall and played pool at Jillian's in the Metreon which are both within walking distance of the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent accommodations”
Reviews.Author: RoroToronto
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just returned from a little getaway to San Francisco. We normally would have tried to stay somewhere a little more centric, but couldn't resist staying at this brand-new hotel. It is beautiful, simple, elegant and comfortable. Nothing too snazzy, but sparkling clean and beautiful neat lines in the design. I cannot overemphasize how spotlessly clean it is, and how promptly the room gets made up daily. The fitness room is great, although my husband complained that it didn't have a pull-up bar. The restaurant and bar are gorgeous, but the food is, IMHO, quite bad. I don't care if food is overpriced if I am in for a satisfying gastronomic experience, but the food there was absolutely nothing special. There are many fabulous restaurants in the city, so give those a try. Also, when we consulted one of the concierges there for a good sushi place, he directed us to a really crappy downtown joint. He kept emphasizing how "reasonable" it was. I guess because we look young (we're in our 20s) he thought we would only want cheap. The place he sent us to was not good, and pretty unreasonable considering the quality! Overall, the staff at the hotel was curteous (although we didn't really need to interact with them for anything - we had no complaints!) and the hotel is a wonderful retreat after a busy day of shopping, going to museums and bustling about that great city! Oh yeah, the beds are WONDERFUL...the pillows not so much.

Reviews.Title: “Business Hotel lacks atmosphere and service”
Reviews.Author: acehole007
Reviews.Content: Stayed here on business November 2008. Rooms were clean, facilities good and the bar staff friendly. Service was very poor especially for US standards. Rude check in staff and rude waitresses - probably because they were understaffed. - asked for more coffee - "its not my first day" was the reply. Several guests walked out at breakfast refusing to pay as there was no food and no plates! Being British we said nothing at the time but due to the rudeness we did inform the manager at checkout. I wouldn't go back and other hotels we visited with clients had much better levels of service. One to avoid although the hotel itself was OK the manager should be sacked.

Reviews.Title: “Luxury in the heart of SoMa”
Reviews.Author: ExtraPickles
Reviews.Content: The InterContinental San Francisco was a luxurious way to end my trip to the Bay Area. The room was in good shape and modern in style. High end room amenities in the bed/living room included: a touch screen phone; Frette bathrobes; computerized minibar; flat screen TV; and an electronic do not disturb/clean room indicator. Room service offered a wide range of options for my breakfast. The room service operator and deliveryman were very professional. The Fitness Center had a decent amount of free weights and cardio machines. I especially liked the personal headsets and TVs that were featured with each treadmill. The temperature of the pool was delightfully warm. Goggles were provided for the underwater swims. In the Business Center, computer terminals had a home page that link to the major airlines' check-in/boarding pass systems. This, unlike other printing services in the center, was free of charge. The only thing I'd change about the hotel was the price of parking. $46+tax was rather steep, even with in/out privileges. Via Hotwire, the room cost less than $150. To get that many services and perks for that cost was a great treat.

Reviews.Title: “Is it an hotel or an airport lounge?”
Reviews.Author: SPD1611
Reviews.Content: This must be the very edge of gentrification in SoMa. 5th Street after dark is getting a touch too much for European visitors - better to come in from 4th. The hotel claims to be almost brand new but several of the fixtures in the bedroom (14th floor) were starting to feel tired. If you like to spend your quality time with dressed down business men wearing conference badges from the convention centre next door then this is for you. The lobby and bar area must have been designed by the team that does Airline Invite Only lounges. Personally, I prefer the grace and charm of the Mark Hopkins up the hill. In IHG terms I reckon this is Crowne Plaza rather than Intercontinental.

Reviews.Title: “New Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Reisefuedli
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the New InterContinental San Francisco. Good location, next to Market Street. Everything is new, design very modern. Rooms are convenient, but lack charme. I preferred to stay at the InterContinental Mark Hopkins on Nob Hill, where I stayed last year. I guess it is great for convention visitors. Did not have a chance to test the restaurants. Staff is friendly.

Reviews.Title: “Great if you can get a good rate”
Reviews.Author: InstantNoodles
Reviews.Content: Staying at the InterContinental San Francisco was a sharp departure from where I normally stay while vacationing in San Francisco. I have had the pleasure at staying at all three of Mobil-rated five-star hotels in San Francisco and wanted to try something different this time around. I gave the hotel five-stars in consideration of the how much I paid for the room and all the amenities I received. If I paid, say $300 or $400 for the room only, I would have gave the hotel three stars. I wanted to share some of my tips for staying at this particular hotel. For California residents, IC offers a â€œStaycationâ€� package which is inclusive of valet parking ($46 + tax per night), buffet breakfast for two including gratuities and taxes (otherwise, $25 per person) and a $10 credit to your guest folio. I HIGHLY recommend this package to California residents. You have to find the package on the hotelâ€™s website under the â€œExperience Moreâ€� tab and book from there. I was given a rate of $159 for a Standard roomâ€”this rate is the same as their â€œBest Available Rateâ€� which is normally reserved for the room only. Since this hotel is buried within the city, there are really no â€œviewsâ€� to speak of. There are only different vantage points depending on what floor you are staying on. I believe the hotel goes up to the 33rd floor? I recommend booking the room with the most appealing rate and asking for an upgrade at check-in (whether it is gratis or you pay a small â€œupgradeâ€� fee). Keep in mind you need to add 14% accommodations tax (this is the â€œsales taxâ€�) to your room rate. This hotel has a club lounge and here are my thoughts about it. Generally when you book a room with Club Access (for two people), you will be on the 31-33rd floor and it will be about $100 more than a comparable room. If you want Club Access and want to save some moneyâ€¦when you check-in (if the option is available) the supplement is $80 (for two people)- you save $20. The caveat is you could be on any one of the 33 floors of the hotel. The club lounge is open from 6:30 AM to 10:30 PM. Unless youâ€™re staying on a corporate account, this option really does not seem worth it to me. Can two people really eat $80 worth of food? Each additional guest is $40. I would much rather pay $100 for club access if it were the Ritz-Carlton (this option is available at the Ritz San Francisco). Club access affords you food presentations throughout the day, internet access WITHIN the club lounge, and various reading materials and possibly garment pressing (not sure). Other reviewers have mentioned the amenities in the room so I will forgo my usual review and give a synopsis of little quirky things about the hotel. Check-in is at 3 o clock PM and check-out is Noon. Your room is fully equipped with an automated mini-bar (similar to Las Vegas) and it will charge you when you remove something almost instantly (even if you put it back). A Snickers bar costs $6.50. A small coke costs $4.00. When you order room service, you are automatically accessed a $3 delivery surcharge, 18% gratuity, and local sales tax (8.5%). The hotel offers a complimentary shoe shine. Housekeeping did not turn down the room (so no bottled water available although Evian is available for $8). Make sure you make a reservation for breakfast if you receive a breakfast coupon as there was a wait at 9 in the morning. Although that time is generally when people eat breakfast anyways, I normally never have to make reservations because a table is usually available. I tried to check-in at 8 in the morning but no room was available. When I came back at 12, the helpful front desk agent was able to put me in a room then. I did not look at the fitness or pool facilities so I have no comment. When I was checking-out I tried to contact the Bell Desk to have someone help take my luggage downstairs to no success. Each time, the line was busy. My car was brought up in 5 minutes. Overall, if I gauged what I paid for the room and the amenities I received, it was a GREAT DEAL. If I could procure the same rate again, I would definitely jump at the chance. I would not pay more than $250 for the Standard room I stayed in.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Irishgirl_286
Reviews.Content: We arrived in San Francisco after a short stay in San Jose with relatives in mid September. All I can say is wow it is much colder in San Francisco so make sure to take along a warm top or jacket. When we arrived at the hotel we were greeted by friendly staff. The hotel lobby is uber modern but somewhat lacking in atmosphere. We ate and drank down along the pier and there was a good atmosphere in the hard rock cafe at pier 39. The hotel room was very nice, clean and modern. There was also a great view from our room. You will need to take a taxi to the pier but you are just a short walk from union square. Overall 10/10.

Reviews.Title: “Impressive new ICH in San Francisco”
Reviews.Author: thebeerhunter
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this property and booked the California Staycation package that they are offering to CA residents through the end of the year. The package includes free parking, a $20 gas card, and breakfast for 2 at their restaurant in addition to the room. We had booked a regular room but at check-in on a Friday night, were offered an upgrade to a club room for an additional $40. We decided to do the upgrade since we were feeling peckish and were pretty certain we could get our money's worth in free drinks and snacks at the lounge. As it turned out at checkout they did not have a gas card to give us, so they gave us the room upgrade for free instead -- OK by us. The hotel is very modern looking, quite striking really. The check in was pretty quick and efficient and we found our way to our room easily enough. We were on the 32nd floor, and found the floor-to-ceiling windows a great touch. The room however was a bit on the small side, and the bath was one of the smallest we've had at an ICH property that we've ever stayed at. Still, it was very clean and comfortable with great bedding (as usual). The lounge is the smallest we've experienced, too, at any ICH property, although there is a big outdoor area so when it's not cold or raining one could escape the slight clausterphobia of the indoors by sitting out on the patio. Being on a higher floor ended up being slightly annoying, at least when it came to the elevators. Even though there are 4 of them, it seemed that whichever elevator came up to get us would also be the one to stop on each floor going down along the way. We learned to not take the first elevator that would come up, so that we could avoid stopping literally 5-10 times on our way down to the lounge or the lobby. It's a very nice property, despite previous posters if you know SF it's a good location. It was a particularly great deal getting the Staycation package, since $50/night parking is ridiculous (though tip for anyone who doesn't know: there is a parking garage charging far less right around the corner on Mission). We'd definitely stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Can't Wait to Go Back!”
Reviews.Author: AEbunny
Reviews.Content: Earlier this year I stayed at the InterContinental for my birthday. The hotel was only a month old and is only a few blocks away from my work so I'd seen the building during it's entire construction process. On the outside it looks very hip and modern. On the inside, it's just as cool and hip. The hotel is beautiful and many aspects of it are top notch. As a San Francisco resident, I like to stay at hotels in the city for leisure and to spend "just the two of us" time with my boyfriend. I must say that this is hands down one of my favorite hotels in San Francisco. It has a completely different angle of luxury than other high end hotel establishments in the city; it's very laid back, welcoming, friendly and not pretentious. I booked 2 rooms for me and my friends to stay and hang out in for the birthday occasion: one deluxe king room and one double room. Both rooms had luxurious amenities. The beds were very comfortable with great sheets and down comforters. The room had a 42" LCD TV with all HD Channels. The bathroom robes were Frette and the mirrors were anti-fog. It's nice to be able to take a shower and not have to aerate the room to finish getting ready for the night! The staff here is very friendly and really tries to make sure their customers are happy. The location of the hotel is perfect. You're still in a good area of downtown San Francisco yet away from all the craziness of Union Square (but only 2 blocks away from main shopping areas). It's a great option for visitors who want an alternative to Union Square hotels. I always feel that Union Square hotels are expensive for what they offer so if you're looking for a beautiful larger room for the same price, this is the place for you. There are 2 things that you should be aware of when you stay here. Overnight parking at the hotel is a bit steep. It's about $47.00 a night per car. The valet people here are nice and you get "in and out" privileges. Also the mini-bars are motion censored for each item. I do not advise that you take any contents out so you can make room to put something in of your own (my friends staying in the double room did this). The second you take the item out it'll get charged to your room, even if you put the item back right away. The process to get the charges reversed and funds back into my account is kind of a pain so hopefully you all won't make this mistake as well. I'll actually staying at the InterContinental again this weekend and I can honestly say that I'm looking forward to it! :)

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Stay ( ...some value quibbles ).”
Reviews.Author: Pino_Spetzberg
Reviews.Content: Stayed here October 08. Door staff very welcoming and friendly, booked into room very efficiently, all staff we met during our stay were very nice. On entering the room first thing you notice is the superb floor to ceiling windows with lovely view across the bay. Great ! No housekeeping issues, the room was spotlessly clean, as was the whole hotel. One evening we were warned to avoid a spilled drink on entering the elevator, by the time we had dumped our shopping in the room and returned to the lobby - it had been cleaned up. The bathrooms have no tub on 28th floor, I believe only the top three floors have tubs - other rooms are just showers. Like many newer hotels the bathroom doors slid closed but did not lock - could be annoying. The flatscreen tv had excellent reception, unlike some other hotels we visited on our trip. The in-room safe was very shallow, unable to store cameras unless very compact size. Hotel location turned out much better for us than we expected. Bloomingdales is just one block away, with the Market Street cable cars also handy. Union Square is a close walk, and as we were walking around the city it felt a better area around the hotel than around Union Square actually. The huge Westfield shopping mall is within the block so the usual food court options are available whilst open. Directly across the road from the hotel is The Chieftain Irish Bar, which had a good choice of local brews, really tasty fish and chips and burgers - and of course, draught Guinness. The staff in here were very friendly also. A few quibbles. The hotel valet parking is $52.44, fair enough for those requiring valet, if expensive. No mention is made that a huge self-park garage is directly behind the hotel @ $30. Hotel website could refer to nearby self-park option. The Visit Luce insert offering a complimentary glass of wine for every entree dish ordered during dinner. Whoopee-do ! Sofitel does this much better offering a complimentary glass of wine or beer at the hotel bar/restaurant - even without ordering food. Often we go on to order more drinks and/or food at a Sofitel after the free drinks - the offer at Luce - we didn't bother. Actually, the Luce bar itself is rather like an airport departure lounge, sited awkwardly opposite the elevators. Not very enticing, but again the staff were great. Final quibble, the bottled water, Evian if I recall, available to guests @ $8 per bottle. We bought some at a nearby deli exactly the same @ $1.20 per bottle. Nobody appreciates being hosed. Our previous night at a Hampton Inn @ $79 rate had two complimentary bottles of water in room. We paid $250 at the Intercontinental. Previously in SF we stayed at Fisherman's Wharf or Union Square, without doubt we preferred staying in SoMa area and will do so in future. To sum up, for us this hotel was an excellent choice, the view of the sunrise across the bay, the cleanliness, location and friendly staff, mean we will definitely stay here next time in SF. Thank you Intercontinental San Francisco !

Reviews.Title: “Truly a wonderful Hotel”
Reviews.Author: drewdallas
Reviews.Content: My partner and I came to this hotel for our marriage ceremony and were comepletely suprised at how beautiful the hotel was. Everything in our room was perfect. The staff, the pool, everything. Thank you Intercontinental!

Reviews.Title: “Overall fantastic”
Reviews.Author: minnie_n
Reviews.Content: The service was fantastic, the room was comfortable and modern. Fantastic view, nice bed, flat screen tv, large spacious bathroom, etc. It was both tasteful and modern without trying too hard. Staff were attentive and friendly. The location is close to the Moscone Center in SOMA, an area that keeps pushing the gentrification boundaries farther and farther (and this is a big symbol of that). This is the place to stay on business, not on a romantic trip (because there are better locations for that). This is one of those hotels that likes to charge for services a la carte, so be prepared for that.

Reviews.Title: “Good value for the price”
Reviews.Author: slecombre
Reviews.Content: Had the junior suite. Nice view but why did they put the desk and the TV in front of the windows? Great bed and nice view from the bathroom. Good breakfast and nice location. On the minus side: the staff is just useless. At check-in they refused to include breakfast into my rates despite what was stated on the internet site. I had to come back to show them on MY computer that they were wrong. I did not appreciate their attitude of sureliness. Otherall I would say it is a good hotel because of the location (between SOMA and market street) but some weak details (staff, entrance and check-in) and it is way too businessmen oriented.

Reviews.AuthorLocation: In the shadows of Pikes Peak
Reviews.Title: “Anticipate delays/problems - overall and ok experience.”
Reviews.Author: CO-TriGirl
Reviews.Content: LONG STORY SHORT - stay here if you know EXACTLY what you want to do and do not rely on hotel staff for ANYTHING! We arrived in SFO around noon - and thought we would try and check in. It was no suprise that our room was not available. We didn't expect our rooms to be available but thought we might try anyway. We checked our bags in with the bellman - who was exceptionally accomodating and offered discounts to the spa and adjacent shopping areas. We were in town for the Nike Women's Marathon and had asked for directions to Union Square. We were suprised by the close proximaty of all of the shops and restaurants in between! Returned around 3:30pm to check back into our hotel when the front desk notified us that the room was not available. No solution or appology was offered for this inconvenience. I had asked if they had an executive lounge and had requested to have access until our room was available. They did make this accomodation and the "IC" club was appropriately staffed and had nice amenities. We received our room key approximately 45 minutes later and proceeded to our room. We were mortified that the room was occupied by another guest at the hotel. Luckily for both parties, everyone was fully dressed (I actually read this happening to another tripadvisor reviewer). We returned to the executive lounge and discussed our situation. They appologized and we incurred a half hour delay with the next room assignment. The new room was nice and clean - beds were comfortable. The staff sent a fruit plate with an appology . Once in the room, we called to have our bags delivered to the room. After waiting an hour, we went to the lobby to aquire them ourselves. There was no appology or assistance and were rudely handed our bags. Here is some info on the rest of the property: POOL/HOT TUB/WORK OUT AREA - the pool is a lap pool only - and is nice and clean. The hot tub had an over abundance of chlorine which made our eyes water. We notified the management but was in the same condition the following day. SPA - just ok. We have been in lavish spas...and this is definately the lower end of the scale. Typically there is a great place to hang and relax with the girls prior to and after the treatment - well - don't expect to do this at the spa. There is no separate hot tub area either. We were directed to the pool area when I asked. The shower/make-up area can only accomodate two people and I had difficulties keeping the water warm in the shower. There were three of us who booked 50 minute deep tissue massages - and we all agreed that the treatments were mediocre at best. Definately not worth the price. CONCIERGE - don't waste your time with him. He is useless. Dinner Recommendations: We called for a recommendation for seafood and reservations and we were directed to a dive. Waste of a cab fare and our time. Even the Cabbie was concerned when we arrived at the restaurant. So the Cabbie had much better recommendations for fantastic seafood! Alcatraz Tour: We had called the concierge twice about the alcatraz tour and he noted it was sold out both days. We decided to "chance" it the second day (at the advice of a local) and show up at the dock and got in without a hitch. Once again - he was useless. So, for those future travelers out there - if the trip is all "booked up" - they do take standbys and can typically accomodate all who show up. We recognized that dealing with the concierge was an exercise in futility and no longer entrusted in him for the remainder of the stay. WHAT THEY DON'T TELL YOU: Stay away from 5th Street at night. It is a know area where drug deals frequently occur. We wondered down Fulsom Street for some GREAT food (definately try Basil) and heard about the drug dealers from the locals. Even our Cabbie wouldn't drive down 5th Street. Fulsom Street is a little sketchy - but there were a few diamonds in the rough that were worth dinning at. Just make sure you take a cab both ways. Also, if you are into the night club scene...check out Butter. OMG was it fun!

Reviews.Title: “Great View!”
Reviews.Author: DfromOC
Reviews.Content: Just got back from the last two night of our honeymoon spent at the IC. First the bad (or the not-as-good if you have a glass-full outlook on life): -Parking is like $48/night. I realize this is San Francisco we're talking about, but $48? Really? Is that necessary? It's more punitive than anything. The valet was pretty slow too. -Location is sort of blah. The SoMa thing is improving but it's still a hike to anywhere other than the Moscone center. We walked it numerous times but the neighborhood is just sort of blah until you get to Market or toward the ferry building. -Breakfast. This was our fault. We were sort of in a rush and we stopped in for breakfast on our way out of town. The buffet was out for $25 including coffee/juice, but we felt that was a little excessive. Instead we opted for off the menu choices. They were okay but were still pretty darn expensive. If I had a do over I would have done the buffet but more likely I would have grabbed a couple of Egg McMuffins instead. There's just no other place to eat within a several block radius unfortunately. Now the good: -The place is sparkly and still seems very new. Everything is very clean. -Being that it was our honeymoon, we splurged a little on one of the exec corner rooms. The view was awesome. We had the sun setting right behing city hall from our room. We didn't face the bay but our view of downtown was gorgeous. The room itself was really big. The bed was incredibly comfortable. I slept the best I have in a very long time. The bathroom was big too and I just love the floor to ceiling windown right next to the toilet. There's nothing quite like sitting next to a floor-to-ceiling window 26 floors up. The flat screen TV is huge and a nice touch as well. -Overall, the good outweighed the bad to be honest even if it doesn't seem that way from above. One should never eat in a hotel restaurant, that was our fault. We were roadtripping, so parking was kind of our fault too. A side note: I went to the business center to catch up on my email. Spent 10 bucks for 20 minutes of service, expensive, but certainly not unheard of. Some woman walked in in a bad mood. She sat down to one of the terminals. She asked about the fee to print. She was annoyed and said she just wanted to print a boarding pass. It turns out this is free if you click that option before paying the 10 bucks. Even though I wasn't doing this, I had seen the option. It was totally obvious. She proceeded to basically rip into the poor girl working the place who explained to her she wasn't able to give her the 10 bucks back. I'm sure a manager could easily fix this for her. But she then went off on the service in the restaurant and how she would never stay there again since she has stayed at so many high-end hotels. First of all, I don't care how good the restaurant is supposed to be, if you come to San Francisco and eat in the hotel restaurant...you're just not very smart. Sorry, I don't know how else to put it. Secondly, people who get condescending and choose to take it out on people they perceive as lower than them have a special place waiting for them someday. Sorry, I needed to vent.

Reviews.Title: “Nice building - bad service!”
Reviews.Author: BIZZYBEENewYork
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for my honeymoon for 7 nights. Bad or non-existent housekeeping for everyday that we stayed. They pick up the phone after many rings on most occasions. They persistently apoiogize for the bad service but were of no help in actually FIXNG the problems. The building is beautiiful and new and the room was huge with great views from a high floor. Weird things abou the place, its a luxury hotel with a high price tag, yet no employee ever opens the front door or says "hello" or "welcome back" when you come in, even though they are standing right there! The housekeeping was the biggest problem during the stay, they are untrained and completely unsupervised. In a city like San Francisco with a million high end hotels stacked on top of each other, pick a different one than this!

Reviews.Title: “Truly Impressive”
Reviews.Author: Strathallan
Reviews.Content: Everything you would expect from a new purpose-built city-centre hotel operating under the InterContinental brand. An impressive property, with deluxe accommodation. Stylish, contemporary, and well-equipped bedrooms, with well-designed lighting and modern bathrooms. Hotel locations in San Francisco can be hit and miss - this is certainly better than some, with Powell Street BART station and cable car terminus just a couple of blocks away. Good breakfast service in the ground-floor restaurant.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic”
Reviews.Author: Oahu3
Reviews.Content: I am totally happy with my descision to stay at this hotel. It truly could not have been any better. The service, overall, was through and unobtrusive, the front desk staff was quick and efficent, the room was great, and the bar and cocktails were top notch. What truly set this property above others was the excellent Concierge staff. Will was without peer. I would not hesitate to stay here again and I plan on doing so.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location”
Reviews.Author: itsthursdaynext
Reviews.Content: We recently stayed at the Intercontinental Hotel for 4 nights. It was a great location for shopping the Union Square/Market area and was a few blocks from the trolley. I would request a high floor as there is some street noise, although the lowest floor with rooms on it is still 7 floors up. The valet service is expensive if you have a car, we decided to leave our car in the huge self parking garage directly behind the hotel. This saved us maybe $30 a night and is a good option if you will be mostly walking or using the trolley. If you will be in and out alot with your car, use the valet. The rooms were large and comfortable, I would say for what you're paying the cleaning staff could have been a little more detail oriented. There was something sticky at the bottom of the mini bar, no battery in the scale in the bathroom, a crumpled tourist map under the night stand, and the last guest's room key on the ice bucket tray. I left a note, and it was promptly taken care of, but come on. Bottom Line: Great Location, comfy bed, but nothing that wins my loyalty when staying in SF

Reviews.Title: “amazing windows and great location”
Reviews.Author: 11thchild
Reviews.Content: I called the hotel directly on the day of the stay (a Saturday night). My in laws live across the Bay and we left our daughter with them so that my husband and I could celebrate my birthday in the city. When we arrived at the front desk I was told that we were upgraded. We had an amazing view corner room on the 22nd floor. Everything was sparkling clean and new. The bed was very comfy and the location was great...just a short walk to Union Square. They gave us a 2pm check out for the next day. We had breakfast in the very quiet restaurant. It was good--not spectacular. They have a very tiny lap pool that was filled with an overabudance of children so we did not use the pool. The room also had nice, plush robes. The valet people were very friendly and helpful. A lot of the rooms in SF are funky and small but this was very nice and modern with bigger rooms. For my husband and myself it was a great room just to hang out in and enjoy each others company without our daughter. We were not really sight seeing tourists as much as just wanting a relaxing get away.

Reviews.Title: “Great location friendly service!”
Reviews.Author: rborjes
Reviews.Content: Great location! only four blocks from Union Square. walking distance to SFMOMA. Bed was awesome. Very close to shopong center. excellent restaurant just a block away, Chez Papa, highly recommended. would definetely stay again.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel”
Reviews.Author: heres_trouble
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel for the last 5 nights of our honeymoon. Our rate was $279 plus tax. On arrival we were upgraded to a King Exec room on the 10th Floor. Very clean room, comfortable beds. We used room service - good food and prompt service. Unlike an earlier contributor we did have a bath in our bathroom. Didn't use concierge so can't comment on that service, front desk were very helpful on arrival. Very business orientated so if staying on business doubt you'd have any complaints. Good location, good service however compared to other hotels on our trip I don't feel this hotel presented good value for money when staying for leisure. Only complaints were the noise at this hotel (waking regularly to the sound of the fire engines passing by the hotel throughout the night) and the $1.50 charge to use the phone, we were not charged for using international dialing cards at the other hotels we stayed at on our honeymoon so this was a bit of a surprise especially one morning when we experienced problems so dialled out several times in order to gain connection only to be charged about $12 by the hotel for this pleasure :-/ Small things but slightly annoying.

Reviews.Title: “Very nice hotel”
Reviews.Author: STSAVER
Reviews.Content: A very very nice hotel. We stayed here for the final three nights of our Honeymoon in August 2008. On arrival we were congratulated on our recent marriage, upgraded to a corner room on floor 27 with floor to ceiling windows in conjunction with the level of my Priority Club membership, and also given a map and details of the city along with being informed of the area nearby that is best to avoid. The room offered great views of the Union Square area of the city. I had read that the hotel was close to an undesirable neighbourhood, but we were not bothered by this in any way during our stay. Turn right and right again out of the hotel and within a few minutes you're on Powell Street so nothing to worry about and we did walk back to the hotel after dark as well. On our second day a bottle of sparkling wine was left in our room on ice with further congratulations offered in a card from the hotel. All in all, a very pleasurable stay in a very nice hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Sweeping city views”
Reviews.Author: WB3
Reviews.Content: This is a great new hotel in San Francisco close to the Convention Centre and the main shopping area. I had the luxury of staying in one of the well appointed junior suites. These are located on the corners of the building so the room has huge floor to ceiling windows on two sides (also extending into the bathroom). The room was huge, complete with iPod docking station, huge flat screen TV and a massive bathroom with a walk-in double shower at one end. All the staff were courteous, especially the cheerful spa staff and my three night stay was very pleasant.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing Hotel!!”
Reviews.Author: mfost
Reviews.Content: This was an amazing hotel! We booked through expedia and got a very reasonable rate (somewhere around 150 per night). We arrived around 11am and our room was ready, which was an unexpected surprise. The rooms were small but comfortable, and had wicked flat screen tv's, ipod alarm clock decks, and beautiful stall showers with great water pressure! Best of all, the beds were rediculously comfortable! The hotel was in a great location - within walking distance to Union Square, movie theatres, and great shopping. I should also note that there was a great restaurant called Bucca right across the street. The gnocci was out of this world! The concierge was particularly helpful! We wanted to eat at cheesecake factory but heard that there tends to be a 1 to 1.5 hour wait during dinner hours. We had our concierge call (eventhough they dont' take reservations), and we waited no more than 2 minutes. Brilliant! This was an incredible hotel and I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it for one second!

Reviews.Title: “Highly recommended, not without faults though”
Reviews.Author: markobmf
Reviews.Content: This is a brand new hotel with all modern amenities. The offerings were comprehensive and at a 4-4.5 star level. We booked a superior room and were "upgraded" to a deluxe room on the 9th floor with no view but were given the option to wait for a room on a higher floor which we declined. The room was huge and the bathroom had full window frontage which is rare in hotels. This made the bathroom deluxe in my opinion and the stand up shower was fine and preferred to old fashioned tubs. Bed was pillow top but on the firm side. Linens were nice. There was a huge LCD tv as well. Overall, the room was extremely comfortable and tastefully decorated. The service was excellent as well, I called down a few minutes prior to check out to have boarding passes printed and they were waiting for me when I checked out. I recall a similar experience at a Westin in NY when I was directed to the business center for a 20 minute ordeal, most of which was the staff member trying to get the hotel computer billing system to work so they could add the $4 to my bill. A big negative was that the room was adjacent to the ice machine room and stairwell (room 902). Though not often, a loud crashing noise came from the ice machine as it filled buckets. The stairwell was used aggressively, why I don't know, at around 3am each night of my stay. It was situated directly behind the headboard and the noise reverberated throughout the room and of course woke each of us up. I suspect it was a staff member checking for breakfast order cards in a manner as efficient as possible for him or her, but I'm not sure. If you wish not to be woken, ask for a room that is not adjacent to these service areas as there are two like this on each floor. This is the only reason why I didn't go five stars all the way because the hotel was truly worthy in other respects.

Reviews.Title: “Loved this hotel!”
Reviews.Author: Saraheartburn
Reviews.Content: This is one beautful glass towering hotel. I was amazed at how well the hotel spaces were designed and the amount of thought that was put into the selection of furniture, wall paper, art, colors, tiles, and granite and fixtures in the bathrooms. I probably would define the spaces as comtemporary with emphasis on clean lines, comfortable textures, warm but neutral tones. The hotel is situated about three blocks south of Union Square and I appreciated itâ€™s location. The area is clean, spacious, safe, and without the crowds and noise of Union Square. It only added to that laid back San Franciscan attitude. The walk is short and easily managed with luggage from the Powell BART station. Bart is faster and way cheaper ($5.35) than a cab from the airport. It is a clean, efficient, comfortable travel mode. I think one of the problems with the hotel is that they have so many codes including different rooms and packages that even the staff gets a bit confused. I had booked a 400 square foot room with two queen beds in the corner on a lower floor, like 7 to 11 for $229 including breakfast. Well, this doesnâ€™t exist. These corner rooms (two walls of windows) only have one bed We were given a 400 sq. foot room with two queen beds that oddly was a bit claustrophobic but not in a corner. When I spoke with Janet, the manager, she could not bend over backwards enough to rectify the situation. We were upgraded to the 28th floor with bay view, slightly smaller room (you would never know it) 360 sq. feet with 2 double beds. It was amazing. She took us around to view several rooms AND gave us vouchers for drinks at the bar. The bay view during the day was lovely but even better at night with the lights of the city. Looking at the city view from the hallway, it was pretty spectacular too, especially at night. The room had an ironing board, iron, hairdryer, umbrella, extra pillows, and blanket. The pillows on the bed were a bit flat but one call and we had five pillows on each bed! Nice fat ones too. Toiletries are included as well as a magnifying mirror. The bathroom is large, spacious and did have a tub. The first room we had been given did not have a tub but a beautiful shower area instead. The door to the bathroom was a large frosted glass sliding door, very cool. The room had a thermostat for temperature control, and an ihome radio-alarm clock with ipod dock. There was a larger than life flat screen TV. Little buttons on the lamps (on-off control) are lighted at night and the far bed nearer the window has a button on the wall to light up the entry way. We heard no noise from the hall or other rooms. Occasionally at night we heard a siren from an emergency vehicle. There are two phones in the room, one wireless. The concierge was very helpful and offered many options to all of our inquires. Hotel personnel were really nice. And check out was pleasant, fast, and efficient. There is a very pretty lap pool and jacuzzi located on the 6th floor (available to alll) as well as a club room for those that booked a club room floor. You can also purchase club room access for 80 dollars a day with any other room which includes breakfast, afternoon tea, drinks and dessert. Buffet breakfast is amazing, Try to get it included in your rate otherwise, 27 dollars a person. I did notice that there was a coffee urn set up on the bar just before the restaurant area for coffee with take away cups in the morning. And there is a Starbucks on your way to Union Square. Westfield Mall is on your way to Union Square also. They have a food court, eh, and a nice food market, Bristol Farms, in the lower level which offers hot and cold take away meals. The fourth floor of the mall has several good restaurants including Zazil, a innovative mexican restaurant with fabulous Margaritas. Bottom line, I am glad I booked the InterContinental and would stay there again without question.

Reviews.Title: “Great people, good design, missing some little things”
Reviews.Author: Traveldad65
Reviews.Content: My Wife and I were celebrating our 20th anniversary in San Francisco after 4 days biking around Sonoma County. Initial impressions weren't good - my wife had booked the reservation but had used my priority club member number - the front desk wouldn't let her check in until I returned from renting the car. When I arrived from across the street, the front desk attendant was pleasant, when I told him why we were in San Francisco he smiled and said he was upgrading us from a queen delux to a king delux. When we got to the room we found that it was tucked in between the ice machine and the stairwell. The rooms are gorgeous. Our room was spacious with beautiful design and very comfortable bedding and climate controls The rooms are not well sound insulated. Even on the 16th floor, delivery trucks could be clearly heard through the curtain wall. We were woken up at 5:50 AM each morning by the paper boy running up the stairwell to deliver the morning newspapers. On check-out when we complained, the front desk attendant told us she was surprized because people usually just complain about the ice machine in that room. The people in the hotel are pleasant and helpful. The concierge was great - answering all our questions about getting around town. When we were ready for check out he printed our boarding passes and arranged shuttle transport. Good but expected in a hotel in this price range. Everything in the hotel is very expensive - Internet is 15.00 per day. Breakfast is 27.00. Room service is assessed an 18 percent gratuity and a 3.00 room service charge. The location is at the east edge of the financial district - kitty corner from the Yerba Buena gardens and two blocks from the streetcar turn-around at Powell and Market. Just South of the Hotel and you run into the tenderloin district (not a place for the kids)

Reviews.Title: “Loved It”
Reviews.Author: calgurl855
Reviews.Content: I loved the hotel it was amazing. We got a great deal on the hotel website that included valet parking, saved us a lot of money cause it is 46 plus tax at the hotel, but a block up from the hotel parking is 16. The package also included buffet breakfast that was amazing and $40 room credit. Everyone at the hotel was so helpful and service oriented. The only bad was the wireless internet. Come on $15 dollars a day for wireless. Motel 6 has it for free. But other than that loved it. Location was perfect just don't venture west and your okay. It was central to everything. I will definitely come back.

Reviews.Title: “A Comparison of two very good S.F. hotels”
Reviews.Author: tearose
Reviews.Content: My wife and I recently had the opportunity to stay in two very good downtown San Francisco hotels -- the InterContinental, and the Westin Market Street. I can recommend both hotels wholeheartedly. However, my personal favorite (by just a few points) is the InterContinental. For others, the balance might tip the other way. Both are modern hotels, about 33-34 floors in height. The Westin Market Street has the advantage of a location that is slightly closer to Union Square, the symbolic center of San Francisco, and is right in the heart of a busy downtown area, almost adjacent to the new Four Seasons Hotel on Market Street and the St. Regis hotel on Third Street. (The I.C. is about one l.o.n.g block, or 3 short blocks, farther from the center, but is still close.) The Westin also has a very attractive indoor-outdoor restaurant on the quiet back side of the hotel. Rooms at both hotels were similar in size.
